sn4.7:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn4.7:4.2: He spent most of the night practicing walking meditation in the open. As the night faded he washed his feet and entered his dwelling. He lay down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
sn4.7:4.3: The Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha
sn4.7:5.2: You sleep like a loser—what’s up with that?
sn4.7:5.3: You sleep, thinking that the hut is empty.
sn4.7:5.4: You sleep when the sun’s come up—what’s up with that?”
sn4.7:6.2: the weaver, the clinger—to lead them anywhere.
sn4.7:6.3: With the ending of all attachments the awakened Buddha sleeps.
sn4.7:6.4: What’s that got to do with you, Māra?”
